title: 108_hr5182
content: The Act is titled the "Homeland Security Civil Rights and Civil Liberties Protection Act of 2004". The Department of Homeland Security's mission is outlined in the Act. The Act, known as the "Homeland Security Civil Rights and Civil Liberties Protection Act of 2004", amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to ensure that civil rights and liberties are not compromised in efforts to secure the homeland. The Homeland Security Civil Rights and Civil Liberties Protection Act of 2004 amends the Homeland Security Act of 2002 to establish an Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties. Section 705(a) of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to ensure that the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties reports directly to the Secretary and addresses concerns of profiling on the basis of race, ethnicity, or religion. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to address concerns of profiling based on race, ethnicity, or religion by ensuring that civil rights and civil liberties are incorporated into Department programs and activities. The Department is required to develop, implement, and review policies to ensure civil rights and liberties are protected in its programs. It must oversee compliance with legal requirements and coordinate with other officials to ensure program alignment. The Department must protect civil rights and liberties in its programs, coordinate with other officials, and investigate possible abuses. The Department must protect civil rights and liberties in its programs, coordinate with other officials, and investigate possible abuses. Congress must receive reports on programs, policies, and procedures, and investigate complaints of civil rights or civil liberties abuses. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include a section on the protection of civil rights and civil liberties by the Office of Inspector General. The Inspector General of the Department of Homeland Security designates a senior official to coordinate investigations of civil rights abuses and receive complaints. The Inspector General of the Department of Homeland Security designates a senior official to coordinate investigations of civil rights abuses, receive complaints, and initiate investigations of alleged abuses by employees or officials. The Inspector General of the Department of Homeland Security designates a senior official to coordinate investigations of civil rights abuses, receive complaints, and initiate investigations of alleged abuses by employees or officials, including contractors or grantees. The Office of Inspector General ensures personnel receive training for effective civil rights and civil liberties investigations and consults with the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties regarding alleged abuses. The Office of Inspector General coordinates civil rights investigations, consults with the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties on alleged abuses, and provides information on investigation outcomes. The Office of Inspector General collaborates with the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties, providing information on investigation outcomes and referring civil rights matters for further action. The Office of Inspector General must publicize information on filing complaints about civil rights and civil liberties, provide updates on investigations, and report any issues within the Department related to civil rights or civil liberties to the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties. The Office of Inspector General must report weaknesses, problems, and deficiencies related to civil rights or civil liberties within the Department to the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties. The Office of Inspector General reports civil rights and civil liberties issues to the Privacy Officer. Section 222 of the Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to include the requirement for coordination with the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties to ensure programs and policies align with civil rights, civil liberties, and privacy. The Homeland Security Act of 2002 is amended to require coordination with the Officer for Civil Rights and Civil Liberties to ensure that programs, policies, and procedures address civil rights, civil liberties, and privacy considerations in an integrated manner and provide appropriate reports to Congress.
